title.narrative: UNESCO Sexuality Education in School Programme

description.narrative: Main Objective: Increased access to high quality & age appropriate sexuality education & services for young people (aged 10 – 24). Sub-Objectives 1. Strengthen the quality, delivery and effectiveness of comprehensive sexuality education (CSE) curricula to ensure that they are evidence based-gender transformative, and age-and culturally appropriate.2. Ensure access to quality and age appropriate sexual reproductive health information and health services for adolescents and young people (aged 10 – 24) including young people living with HIV (YPLHIV) and those with disabilities in supported project sites.3. Strengthen Zambia’s ability to protect children against sexual violence & harassment in school settings4. Improve community engagement in young people’s access to comprehensive sexuality education & services5. Improve research and evaluation around SRH for young people aged 10 – 24 years to enhance the evidence base for planning and implementation of programmes

Projektet syftar till att införa omfattande sexuell upplysning i skolor i Zambia för att leverera tillräcklig kunskap och information och göra det möjligt för ungdomar att fatta välgrundade beslut om sin sexualitet och sexuell hälsa. Det slutliga målet är att förbättra den sexuella och reproduktiva hälsa, minska oplanerade pregnacies och slutligen lägre avhopp från skolan.

The project aims at introducing Comprehensive Sexuality Education in schools in Zambia in order to deliver appropriate knowledge and information and enable adolescents to make informed choices about their sexuality and sexual health. The ultimate goal is to improve sexual and reproductive Health, reduce unplanned pregnacies and ultimately lower school dropouts.

description.narrative: The Zambian School curriculum and associated guidelines on Comprehensive Sexuality Education were successfully developed and rolled out to all schools reaching 100% of grades 5-12 learners in Zambia, a total of 1,988,251 adolescents and young people. The Examinations Council of Zambia was supported to integrate CSE into national exams for grades 7, 9 and 12. This is a useful tool to assess the knowledge levels of learners in the future. The project trained and oriented teachers, policy makers, parent teachers associations and education administrators in the delivery of CSE. 41,328 in-service and 11,500 pre-service teachers were trained in total. 159,900 learners were referred to services and tracked out of a target of 31,200. This was made possible through partnerships with two CSOs. (Referral made by teachers were not tracked in the same way). Zambia was the first country to include all recommended UNESCO indicators for monitoring the education sector response to HIV, including sexuality education, into its national Education Management Information System (EMIS). Zambia also became a regional leader and and advocate for CSE with the Ministry of Education keen to reduce the number of school dropouts due to adolescent pregnancies and child marriages. In terms of programme impact the number of pregnancies amongst girls enrolled in primary school and secondary school decreased nationally by more than 25% and 15% respectively following the implementation of CSE in Schools. The impact seemed to be higher in primary schools than secondary schools.
